urn:contentItem:5M5K-X2B1-F0JP-W2VF-00000-00Mission of rescue for our crews2016-11-15T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:58:16ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 15Mission of rescue for our crewsERIN PEARSON

MORE than a dozen emergency services workers from Geelong and the Otways are helping in the state's northwest after storms caused chaos in the Mildura region.

Crushed cars and flattened homes have kept officers on their toes with 15 CFA personnel, eight Forest Fire Management Victoria personnel and 14 local SES officers deployed on Saturday.

District 7 CFA operations officer Mark Sinkinson said the damage from Friday's storm had been significant.

"Crews have been working to clear debris and remove large trees from roads. We had personnel assisting with chainsaws and cleaning up," Mr Sinkinson said.

Forest Fire Management Victoria task force leader Hamish Martin said crews had seen cars crushed and trees crashed on to homes.

"We've been to a lot of homes where the residents have been appreciative - particularly those residentswho wouldn't have the -capacity to do the work, such as seniors and people with disabilities," Mr Martin said.Thousands of properties lost power in the storm.

xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Forest fire-fight ban</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>PEGLER T</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">A BREAKDOWN in talks between the Department of Conservation and Environment and the Australian Workers Union has sparked a ban on fire fighting duties.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> Union industrial officer Paul Elliott said up to 1200 forestry workers had placed the bans after the department failed to deal with a union log of claims.</p><p>Union members have banned controlled burns which clear areas in preparation for the bushfire season, manning of firetowers and some training duties.</p><p> Members also have banned stand-by duty which involves remaining on call in case of fires.</p><p> The union and the department are at loggerheads over a claim for a disability allowance to cover exposure to heat, smoke, dust and danger when firefighting.</p><p> It placed similar bans in August but industrial action was lifted after they agreed on allowances for protective clothing and chemical spraying.</p><p> Mr Elliott said a "paltry" offer by the department provoked the industrial action.</p><p> TIM PEGLER</p><p> END OF STORY</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata urn:contentItem:5VG8-N541-F0J6-J1WY-00000-00Fairy grass concern continues2019-02-20T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:58:16ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 6Fairy grass concern continuesJade Bate

MR Wilson said he was concerned about the fire risk fairy grass caused on Total Fire Ban days.

"If a pilot light or powerline sparks, then you have no break between the grass and the house. The grass is very combustible and can move around so easily," he said.

Parks Victoria area chief ranger Zoe Wilkinson said Parks Victoria had been in regular contact with Clear Lake residents.

"Local evidence suggests the best treatment is to allow the natural process of vegetation succession with minimal human intervention. Importantly, Clear Lake also contains registered Aboriginal heritage sites which must be protected when considering any treatment of this native grass," she said.

She said Forest Fire Management Wimmera would assess the Clear Lake fairy grass as part of its fuel management strategy.

urn:contentItem:5TBY-70V1-DYG0-936Y-00000-00VIC:Campfire threat grows ahead of Vic summer2018-09-27T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:58:16ZLexisNexisDOMESTIC NEWSVIC:Campfire threat grows ahead of Vic summerMELBOURNE Sept 27

  An unattended campfire is to blame for a three-hectare blaze in regional Victoria as authorities warn of a worrying trend.
   Since the start of September six fires have been caused by campfire negligence, Forest Fire Management Victoria officer Jarrod Hayse said in a statement on Thursday.
   "Most recently, a suspected unattended campfire caused a three-hectare fire in Kialla (on Wednesday). Luckily fire crews were able to contain the fire before it spread," he said, adding that people found in breach of safety rules can face penalties of more than $16,000.

urn:contentItem:5MNT-Y0J1-F0J6-J3S1-00000-00Glenorchy planned burn2016-12-21T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:58:16ZLexisNexisGlenorchy planned burnSophie Boyd

FOREST Fire Management and Parks Victoria will undertake a planned burn at Arapiles Street and Lower Bunbury Street, Glenorchy on Wednesday.

The burn will ignite at 12.00pm conditions permitting and burn 34 hectares until 6pm Saturday.

Forest Fire Management said the burn would take place 500 metres west of Glenorchy with smoke visible through Glenorchy and on Stawell-Warracknabeal Road.

The Country Fire Authority is working with the departments to reduce the risk of bushfire this coming fire season.

Parks Victoria advises people to stay away from areas where burns are planned or places recently burnt.

Parks advised people to be careful on the roads and aware of potentially lowered visibility and changed signed conditions.

Nearby residents should close all doors and windows and avoid hanging washing outside.

Access to walking tracks, car parks, camping ground and picnic sites may be restricted.

The Department of Health advises people that suffer adverse reactions to seek medical advice or call 1300 606 024.

For more information on the planned burn and traffic conditions visit parkweb.vic.gov.au/ or traffic.vicroads.vic.gov.au

urn:contentItem:5SYR-2VH1-JD3N-522H-00000-00Greek fire MP quits2018-08-05T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:58:16ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 80Greek fire MP quits

GREECE'S public order minister has resigned over the -forest fire that killed at least 87 -people in a seaside area near Athens last week, after spending days defending the way authorities under his supervision handled the disaster.Nikos Toskas and other government officials came under intense criticism from opposition parties over auth-orities' response to the dev-astating fire at Mati, and for his assertion in a press -con-ference that, despite considerable soul-searching, he had not discerned any major errors in how the emergency was handled.

urn:contentItem:5VBB-6XK1-JD34-V0NJ-00000-00Watch and act issued for grass and scrub fire near Hepburn2019-02-03T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:58:16ZLexisNexisWatch and act issued for grass and scrub fire near HepburnMichelle Smith

Fire authorities have issued a watch and act for Elevated Plains, Hepburn, Hepburn Springs, Basalt, Dry Diggings, Mount Franklin, and Shepherds Flat after a grass and scrub fire broke out at Elevated Plains, north of Hepburn, soon after 6.30pm.

Within an hour the CFA, DELWP and Forest Fire Management had deployed at least 35 appliances to try to contain the blaze ahead of hazardous fire conditions on Sunday.

The fire, in the vicinity of Mannings Road, north of Dry Diggings Track, is travelling in a south easterly direction.

Sunday has been declared a day of total fire ban across the state with temperatures around Ballarat forecast to hit 37C, and elsewhere around the state as hot as 42C.

urn:contentItem:5SWK-YM01-JD34-V34N-00000-0045 winter fires in forests2018-07-27T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:58:16ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 245 winter fires in forestsSophie Boyd

Parks Victoria rangers and Forest Fire Management Victoria officers are urging visitors to follow campfire guidelines after responding to 45 unattended campfires on public land this winter.

Chief Fire Officer Darrin McKenzie said people can't be complacent in the cooler months and it was very frustrating when campfires escape and it could have been prevented.

"We want people to get out there and enjoy themselves, but make campfire safety a priority for their trip by knowing what they can and can't do," he said.

urn:contentItem:5TPM-MTJ1-F0J6-J1SB-00000-00Abandoned burning car sets Creswick forest alight2018-11-12T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:58:16ZLexisNexisAbandoned burning car sets Creswick forest alight

A car that had been set alight and abandoned near Creswick Forest quickly spread into the nearby forest at Creswick on Sunday afternoon.

A CFA spokesperson confirmed the fire in Railway Road, Creswick, had started at 2.09pm and was attended at one stage by 10 fire tankers from surrounding fire brigades.

The spokesperson said the fire had taken some time to bring under control and had spread quickly in the dry undergrowth of the pine forest.

There was no risk to people or property but Forest Fire Management had been alerted to attend the scene, he said.

A smaller fire in Princes Street, Creswick, started about 2.45pm but was quickly brought under control.

urn:contentItem:5MP9-TT11-F0J6-J3P9-00000-00Fire burning at Mt Cole2017-01-23T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:58:16ZLexisNexisFire burning at Mt ColeLuke Horton

4.40PM

TEN appliances and crews from the Country Fire Authority and Forest Fire Management Victoria continue to battle an out of control bushfire at Mt Cole.

Several aircraft have also joined the fire-fighting operation, which is in hard to access terrain.

The fire is approximately four kilometres north-east of Warrak in the Mount Cole State Forest.

The authority said there was currently no threat to communities, but people should continue to stay informed and monitor conditions.

3.20PM

CREWS from the Country Fire Authority and Forest Fire Management Victoria continue to battle a bushfire at Mt Cole.

Several aircraft have joined the fire-fighting operation, which is in hard to access terrain about 20 kilometres east of Ararat.

The fire is reportedly near the base of the Ben Nevis Fire Tower.

2.30PM

THE Country Fire Authority is battling a small out of control bushfire at Red Rocks Road near Mt Cole.

The authority has issued an advice notice for people in the Ben Nevis, Elmhurst, Eversley, Mount Cole, Mount Cole Creek, Warrak, Bayindeen and Glenlogie areas.

The fire is near the base of the Ben Nevis Fire Tower.

The authority said the fire was expected to be controlled soon.

ALMOST 50 firefighters battled a blaze in East Bendigo yesterday as temperatures topped 43 degrees.

CFA and Forest Fire Management Victoria units were called to the Harpin Street scene at 12.45pm as plumes of black smoke billowed over Bendigo.

Senior station officer Paul Caligari said the fire took about 25 to 30 minutes to bring under control.

nitf:lede="true">A BUSHFIRE which burnt through 34,000ha of forest in Victoria's Alpine</p><p nitf:lede="true">Park this month has sparked a campaign to repair environmental damage</p><p nitf:lede="true">caused by firefighters.</p><p nitf:lede="true">The blaze dubbed "the Caledonia fire", after the river which runs</p><p nitf:lede="true">through the area, broke out on New Year's Day and frustrated</p><p nitf:lede="true">firefighters for 11 days before they finally hemmed it in with 125km</p><p nitf:lede="true">of control lines around the area north of Licola.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>aap</p></bodyText></section><p>In the process, bulldozers ripped through pristine forest, clearing</p><p>the way for fleets of tankers, helicopters and more than 500</p><p>firefighters.</p><p>Soil on slopes was dislodged and tonnes of sediment dropped into</p><p>waterways during the fire said to have cost the State Government $2</p><p>million.</p><p>Mr Gerard O'Neill, of the Natural Resources and Environment</p><p>Department, said yesterday a small team would take until about June to</p><p>complete a rehabilitation program for the park.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:5S66-KTJ1-F0J6-J3VH-00000-00Planned burns for conservation reserve near Wedderburn2018-04-27T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:58:16ZLexisNexisPlanned burns for conservation reserve near Wedderburn

The Wychitella Nature Conservation Reserve will be subject to a planned burn on Friday.

Forest Fire Management Victoria and CFA will conduct the fuel reduction burn over 250 hectares of the reserve, 1.2 kilometres west of Wedderburn on Wedderburn-White Rock Road.

The burn will be completed between 9am and 8pm on Friday with smoke visible from Wedderburn, Korongvale and Woosang until Tuesday.

Stay updated on planned burns by visiting www.ffm.vic.gov.au/pbns

urn:contentItem:4MM6-N6B0-TXDB-G2RP-00000-00Crews work to contain forest fire north of Adelaide2006-12-20T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:58:16ZLexisNexisCrews work to contain forest fire north of Adelaide

More than 70 firefighters are working to contain a blaze in a forest reserve north of Adelaide.

Authorities were called to the fire at Devil's Gully within the Mt Crawford Forest Reserve, late last night.

Homes are not directly under threat, but several water tankers are on stand-by in case the fire spreads.

South Australian Country Fire Service spokeswoman Krista St John says a wind change could threaten property.

"Although the fire is not large at this time, should the wind increase there is a potential for this fire to quickly spread to homes which are around a kilometre away," she said.

"The CFS has placed a number of appliances on these properties on Kestrell Road, just in case the fire does move and does threaten these homes."

Ms St John says predicted unfavourable conditions today have raised concerns.

"Firefighters are focusing their efforts on developing these control lines in anticipation of hot weather today," she said.

"Their concern is that the wind may increase, push the fire over the gully and threaten homes."

urn:contentItem:5W3N-J8Y1-JD34-V2B0-00000-00Fox baiting program begins2019-05-14T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:58:16ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 5Fox baiting program begins

Fox baiting has started in central Victoria with Forest Fire Management Victoria laying baits in a number of state forests.

Baits have been laid in the Bung Bong, Costerfield, Wellsford, Redcastle, Mount Hoogly and Wareek state forests.

The fox baiting program aims to reduce attacks on native animals and livestock.

FFMVic acting senior forest management and roading officer Joe Rogasch said the program focuses on boundaries between public and private land.

"The 1080 poison shelf-stable baits will be buried in bait stations according to Victorian Directions for Use of 1080 products and manufacturer's guidelines to reduce the risk of non-target species taking them," Mr Rogasch said.

Mr Rogasch said it was important nearby residents and landholders ensured their dogs and other pets were confined to their property during the baiting period.

"We urge pet owners to take note of the signs and keep dogs on leash or muzzled while in or near baited areas," he said.

xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Qld: Forest fire risk worst in eight years</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:dateline>BRISBANE, Aug 19</nitf:dateline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">Residents of new housing developments north of Brisbane could be at risk if bushfires swept out of control through thousands of hectares of plantation forests in the area, a forestry officer warned.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Beerburrum forestry manager Leigh Kleinschmidt said today the area was facing its worst fire threat since 1994 when two wildfires destroyed 5,000 hectares of forest as well as community infrastructure.</p><p>He said the risk of fires in the area was heightened by the extended dry in south-east Queensland which had forced forestry workers to stop hazard reduction burn-offs early.</p><p>"Undergrowth is tinder dry and the threat remains that any fire which starts could easily get out of hand if not reported immediately," Mr Kleinschmidt said.</p><p>He said the fires of 1994 had been the worst in 100 years and had affected businesses because the amount of timber that could be harvested was cut back.<br/></p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source Fire feedback

The Department of Environment, Land, Water and Planning and Forest Fire Management Victoria is still seeking feedback to develop bushfire management strategies across Victoria. Community members are invited to participate in two surveys to test what has been heard so far, and to provide additional comment. Details: bit.ly/2KtxRRw

Witnesses sought

Moorabool Police are calling for help following a series of thefts around Tate Street, Darley in the early hours of May 20. Police have released images of two men who may be able to assist with their inquiries. Anyone with information is encouraged to contact Detective Senior Constable Wilsher on 5366 4545 or visit crimestoppersvic.com.au.

OzChild moves in

OzChild has taken over from The Salvation Army Westcare in providing home-based care services for children and young people in the west. OzChild, which provides foster care and kinship services, will be implementing its KEEP program through it's Melton headquarters. The program is for foster parents of children aged between five and 12 and is aimed at promoting child wellbeing and preventing placement breakdown.

Details: ozchild.org.au

urn:contentItem:5T94-CGX1-JD34-V22H-00000-00Crews prepare for fire season2018-09-19T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:58:16ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 7Crews prepare for fire season

WIMMERA emergency services are in the midst of preparing for fire danger season.

Forest Fire Management Victoria Wimmera District hosted its annual Little Desert Fire Conference last week. Wimmera District manager Glenn Rudolph said the meeting gave emergency services the chance to discuss action plans heading into the season.

"The conference provides the opportunity to strengthen multi-agency partnerships and share knowledge and ideas before we head into what is shaping up to be a demanding spring planned burning program, and an early and active fire season," he said.

"Strategic fuel management planning brings together land and fire managers, communities and stakeholders to develop a common understanding of bushfire risk."

urn:contentItem:5V9X-NNM1-F0JP-W1BJ-00000-00LIGHTNING SETS GRASS ABLAZE2019-02-01T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:58:16ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 5LIGHTNING SETS GRASS ABLAZEOLIVIA SHYING

A LIGHTNING strike is suspected to have reignited a grass and scrub fire at Lake Connewarre yesterday, with firefighters battling the blaze into the evening.

CFA members were first called to the scrub fire, near Belchers Lane, at 5pm on Wednesday. It was soon brought under control by on-the-ground firefighters and a waterbombing chopper.

But about 4am yesterday the fire was reignited after a lightning strike. A VicEmergency update warned the fire was not yet under control as of 6pm yesterday, advising that smoke and flame would be visible from nearby communities and roads.

"Fire is burning in deep layers of vegetation," the warning noted. "Forest Fire Management Victoria firefighters and Fire bombing Aircraft are working to bring the fire under control." "The fire is burning in the Lake Connewarre swamp area, making access to sections of the fire difficult."The fire had burned around seven hectares by 7pm.

urn:contentItem:5VTB-HMF1-JD34-V1GM-00000-00Planned burn near Mount Arapiles2019-04-05T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:58:16ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 2Planned burn near Mount ArapilesAlexander Darling

Eight hectares of scrub around Mount Arapiles was burnt on Thursday, as Forest Fire Management Victoria helped traditional owners prepare for a larger burn later in Autumn.

The organisation's Wimmera district manager Glenn Rudolph said they burned a small strip in Mount Arapiles-Tooan State Park to protect the public toilets in the campsite area.

"It is in preparation for a burn that will be led by the Wotjobaluk community and will take place later this year," Mr Rudolph said. "This is the third year this burn is being done."

Aboriginal planned burns involve lighting fires in places where the flames can take their natural paths.

Thursday's burn followed another planned burn that took place in Little Desert National Park across Tuesday and Wednesday.

Mr Rudolph said this burn was successful.

"We burnt ten kilometres of edge break to stop fire getting in or out of the park, and had no issues," he said. "This marks the start of our autumn burn program."

urn:contentItem:5VSX-R9V1-JD3N-52MX-00000-00Burns set for Otways2019-04-03T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:58:16ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 5Burns set for Otways

PLANNED burns will soon begin in the Otways to reduce the impact of bushfires on the community and environment.

Forest Fire Management Victoria Otway district manager David Roberts said planned burns during autumn would considerably reduce the Otways bushfire risk.

"We will be starting the program with a small but important 8ha burn in Lorne, along Francis St.

"Other larger burns, in Lorne, Aireys Inlet, Anglesea, Gellibrand and Forrest, are priorities for the coming autumn period," he said.

During these burns it is likely there will be significant amounts of smoke visible to the surrounding communities.

Mr Roberts said the burn program was starting later than previous years to achieve the best outcomes in a smaller time frame of suitable weather and fuel conditions He warned there may some disruption to traffic during the burns.For the latest information about when planned burns are happening near you, go to www.ffm.vic.gov.au/plannedburn, download the VicEmergency app or call the VicEmergency hotline on 1800 226 226.

urn:contentItem:5W4H-BM71-JD34-V3RM-00000-00Little Desert fuel reduction burn starts2019-05-18T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:58:16ZLexisNexisLittle Desert fuel reduction burn starts

FOREST Fire Management Victoria will conduct a fuel reduction burn in the Little Desert National Park, starting today.

Wimmera district manager, Glenn Rudolph, said the burn, in a western block of the park, is due to begin at noon on Friday, May 17 and conclude at 6pm.

"The burn objective is to develop fuel reduced areas of sufficient width and continuity to reduce the speed and intensity of bushfires," Mr Rudolph said.

The Department of Health and Human Services said people affected by smoke exposure from the burn should seek medical advice of phone the Nurse on Call on 1300 606 024. They can close windows and doors to prevent smoke from entering.

Road travel might be be hazardous due to low visibility associated with smoke. Signs may be in place to slow traffic; check www.traffic.vicroads.vic.gov.au for travel times and road works.

Access to walking tracks, car parks, camping grounds and picnic sites in areas close to or in burn areas may be restricted; phone Parks Victoria on 13 1963 or visit www.parkweb.vic.gov.au for details.

urn:contentItem:5V6G-RPH1-JD34-V0RF-00000-00Homes saved2019-01-16T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:58:16ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 1Homes saved

FIREFIGHTERS remained in the Macedon Ranges overnight after a bushfire consumed about 25 hectares at Benloch yesterday.

Almost 50 CFA appliances, 10 Forest Fire Management Victoria units and seven aircraft fought the fire, with assistance from a number of bulldozers and graders.

Incident Controller John Pearce praised the firefighting efforts.

At its peak, the blaze posed a threat to homes and lives. The nearest property was 500 metres from the fire.

Nearby residents were told it was too late to leave and advised the safest option was to take shelter indoors immediately.

The fire was contained and declared under control by about 3.50pm.

Mr Pearce said the only reported property losses related to fencing.

There were no reported injuries, and no assets lost.

"From our point of view it as a good fire fight," Mr Pearce said.

Police were investigating the cause of the blaze, which started about 1pm.

urn:contentItem:5T35-6B51-F0J6-J03D-00000-00Planned burns set for Grampians region on Wednesday2018-08-22T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:58:16ZLexisNexisPlanned burns set for Grampians region on Wednesday

Planned burns will be carried out between midday and 6pm on in the Grampians region Wednesday.

Burns will be undertaken at Bringalbert State Forest, Grampians National Park & Millers Bushland Reserve, weather permitting.

Small Bringalbert North and South Heaps, Pomonal and Halls Gap heap burns will be reducing accumulated green waste.

Smoke may be visible from these areas and it may affect individuals nearby.

CFA and Forest Fire Management Victoria urges people to close windows and doors to prevent smoke from entering and be aware of reduced visibility on roads.

People experiencing symptoms due to smoke exposure should seek medical advice or call Nurse on Call on 1300 606 024.

urn:contentItem:5VNX-9T41-F0JP-W2T4-00000-00Steel spikes discovered on forest tracks2019-03-20T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:58:16ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 22Steel spikes discovered on forest tracksBy BETHANY GRIFFITHS

POLICE have stepped up -patrols around the Toolangi State Forest near Kinglake after steel spikes were found hidden on bush tracks.

The spikes were recently found hammered into spots along Martins Track and Breako'day Track, and covered by leaves and debris.

Four Wheel Drive Victoria chief executive Wayne Heavey said he received notice of the incident after multiple people posted on their Facebook page.

"We had a couple of people obviously complaining about the fact that their tyres were destroyed," he said.

Sergeant Matt Wheeler, from Kinglake Police Station, condemned the behaviour, sharing his concerns for the safety of others using the tracks.

"If someone's got an issue with people driving out the bush, it's certainly not the way to deal with it," he said.

"There is the potential for someone to be seriously -injured."Forest Fire Management Victoria has also labelled such action "reckless and dangerous" and a real threat to emergency services.

COMMUNITIES in the Wimmera's south-west are being asked to monitor conditions after a fire started at Jilpanger on Sunday afternoon.

Department of Environment, Land, Water and Planning, Forest Fire Management, and Country Fire Authority crews are at the scene in the Jilpanger Nature Conservation Reserve, about 45 kilometres south-west of Natimuk.

The department has issued an advice warning for people in surrounding communities, which says there is no threat to life but that people should stay informed and monitor the conditions.

The fire is travelling in a north-westerly direction, and smoke will be visible from nearby communities and roads.

The advice message affects Arapiles, Balmoral, Brooksby, Charam, Clear Lake, Douglas, Edenhope, Goroke, Gymbowen, Harrow, Jallumba, Jilpanger, Kanagulk, Karnak, Miga Lake, Mitre, Natimuk, Noradjuha, Nurcoung, Nurrabiel, St Evins, Telangatuk East, Tooan, Tooan East, Toolondo and Wombelano communities.

urn:contentItem:4P0W-XHG0-TXN5-T2FR-00000-00Forest fire the work of an arsonist2004-08-09T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:58:16ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 11Forest fire the work of an arsonistDAMON CRONSHAW

A DELIBERATELY lit bushfire that burnt out 700 hectares of the Awaba State Forest sent plumes of smoke across Lake Macquarie yesterday.

It was one of two bushfires in the Hunter with seven crews fighting a large grass fire on Ash Island, in the Kooragang Wetlands, yesterday afternoon.

It was quickly extinguished and is believed to have had only a slight impact on extensive rehabilitation programs in the area.

State Forests incident controller Peter Tarjanyi said there was no doubt the Awaba fire "was an arson attack, because it started in a very isolated part of the forest and there had been no lightning activity".

He said the fire was contained, but patrols were last night "keeping an eye on trouble spots".

About 35 State Forests and Rural Fire Service personnel fought the fire, which began at about 3pm on Friday and was still burning last night. · FUNDING for a new rural fire station for the Williamtown/Salt Ash area will be discussed by Port Stephens councillors tomorrow night.

Meeting in committee, the councillors will be asked to consider a staff recommendation to allocate $290,000 for construction of the station in Lee Thompson Park.

BACKBURNING: Larry Ward, of State Forests, at Brunkerville yesterday.- Picture by Simone De Peak

COMMUNITIES in the Wimmera's south-west are being asked to monitor conditions after a fire started at Jilpanger on Sunday afternoon.

Department of Environment, Land, Water and Planning, Forest Fire Management, and Country Fire Authority crews are at the scene in the Jilpanger Nature Conservation Reserve, about 45 kilometres south-west of Natimuk.

The department has issued an advice warning for people in surrounding communities, which says there is no threat to life but that people should stay informed and monitor the conditions.

The fire is travelling in a north-westerly direction, and smoke will be visible from nearby communities and roads.

The advice message affects Arapiles, Balmoral, Brooksby, Charam, Clear Lake, Douglas, Edenhope, Goroke, Gymbowen, Harrow, Jallumba, Jilpanger, Kanagulk, Karnak, Miga Lake, Mitre, Natimuk, Noradjuha, Nurcoung, Nurrabiel, St Evins, Telangatuk East, Tooan, Tooan East, Toolondo and Wombelano communities.

urn:contentItem:5V2F-CR21-JD34-V1D4-00000-00Cause of fire deemed suspect2018-12-28T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:58:16ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 2Cause of fire deemed suspect

A BLAZE at Lake Fyans Sunday afternoon has been deemed suspicious by fire investigators.

Country Fire Authority crews were alerted to the blaze at 12.40pm after a recreational fisher spotted smoke along the north eastern end of the lake.

District 16 operations officer Ian Morley said local crews confirmed there was a blaze in the pine plantation along the north eastern shore.

Crews attended from Pomonal, Halls Gap, Stawell, Moyston, and the Ararat Group.

Two fire bombers from Stawell also attended alongside personnel from the Grampians National Park and Forest Fire Management Victoria.

A bulldozer was also sent from Horsham and it took an hour to get the blaze under control.

"The fire was quickly contained but some extensive mopping took place," Mr Morley said.

"Fire investigators responded and it's believed it may be suspicious but we're going out today again."

THE spring firewood collection season will close across Victoria on Thursday.

Forest Fire Management Victoria acting assistant fire control officer Peter Kambouris said all designated firewood collection areas would close from December 1. He said collecting firewood on public land during summer was illegal.

"The public will be able to start collecting firewood again from designated areas from March 1, pending suitable conditions," Mr Kambouris said.

urn:contentItem:5VY6-33N1-JD34-V2D7-00000-00Firefighters extinguish Deep Lead, Bellfield campfires2019-04-23T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:58:16ZLexisNexisFirefighters extinguish Deep Lead, Bellfield campfiresAlexander Darling

Country Fire Authority crews from across the Wimmera and Northern Grampians were called to two campfires at Deep Lead and Bellfield on Monday afternoon.

CFA spokeswoman Jenny Close said crews from Dadswells Bridge, Glenorchy and Stawell brought the Deep Lead fire, at Flat Rock campground, under control at 1.37 pm.

"That fire is now extinguished and the crews are inspecting other campsites in the area," she said.

Ms Close said four vehicles then extinguished the Bellfield campfire, near the intersection of Silverband and Grampians Roads, at 1.54 pm.

Meanwhile, Ararat's firefighters have just extinguished a small blaze in a drum on Montgomery Street.

Ms Close said the fire was lit without a permit during the fire danger period, which ends on May 1 in the Ararat Rural City Council area.

Monday's incidents come as a planned burn three kilometres east of Halls Gap continues.

Forest Fire Management Victoria is burning 2237 hectares around the Boronia track. The organisation said crews would patrol the edge of the burn regularly and deal with hazardous trees.

FIREFIGHTERS have controlled a blaze in the Big Desert Wilderness Park.

Forest Fire Management Victoria crews controlled the fire about 5pm on Saturday, and the Nhill-Murrayville Road has been reopened.

A spokeswoman said the road was in poor condition in some sections because of heavy traffic and advised people to drive to conditions. She said firefighters were still in the area, patrolling the 85-kilometre fire edge. The fire has burnt about 5600 hectares since it started on January 19.

urn:contentItem:5V03-PKT1-JD34-V0YY-00000-00Learning safety education2018-12-17T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:58:16ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 3Learning safety educationJessica Howard

The mobile police command centre which was set up at a bomb site in Derrinallum was just one of many emergency services vehicles on display at Lake Pertobe on Saturday.

The inaugural South West Emergency Services Capability Forum was held in Warrnambool and hosted by the Moyne and Warrnambool Municipal Emergency Management Planning Committee. Agencies spent the morning sharing their specialist knowledge, while the community viewed the equipment in the afternoon and discussed plans for better preparation during an emergency. Agencies included Ambulance Victoria, CFA, VIC SES, DELWP, Forest Fire Management, Coast Guard, Marine Rescue, Victoria Police and Red Cross and more. Hamilton CFA set up a property advice trailer built by the Coleraine Men's Shed. Hamilton CFA's Bobbie-Lee Nelson said the trailer was a visual teaching tool that showed people what a well-prepared home looked like during bushfire season.

  Parched bushland and forecast sweltering heat have prompted a Victorian fire warning for campers over the Australia Day long weekend.
   Temperatures are tipped to hit 39C in Melbourne on Sunday and soar past 40C in other parts of the state on the weekend, with those planning a camping trip warned to remain alert to possible bushfires.
   "The forests and parks are already very dry and the fire danger will be very high,"Forest Fire Management Victoria said in a statement on Wednesday.

urn:contentItem:5G24-TCJ1-DYG0-94VH-00000-00MOTOR:Latvala leads Rally of Portugal2015-05-23T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:58:16ZLexisNexisSPORTS NEWSMOTOR:Latvala leads Rally of Portugal

  MOT WRC
   MATOSINHOS, Portugal, May 22 AFP - Finn Jari-Matti Latvala leads Kris Meeke of Britain at the Rally of Portugal after Friday's action was disrupted by a forest fire.


   Volkswagen's Latvala holds an 11sec cushion over Meeke, the in-form Citroen DS3 driver aiming to follow up on his win last time out in Argentina.
   A second Volkswagen of Andres Mikkelsen lies third, 16s off the pace, with the German constructor's world champion Sebastien Ogier only sixth.
   The forest fire caused the second stage to be abandoned and the third stage cancelled altogether.
   Saturday's second day continues with special stages in the region to the east of Porto.
   AFP gjw

urn:contentItem:5VCD-5GY1-F0J6-J4F1-00000-00Lake activities off limits as warnings remain in place2019-02-08T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:58:16ZLexisNexisLake activities off limits as warnings remain in placeBrian Allen

Lake Bullen Merri remains off limits to the public while a blue-green algal bloom is present in the water.

The Department of Environment, Land, Water and Planning continue to test and monitor the lake, near Camperdown, for the bloom which was confirmed on November 28.

The public was advised to avoid all water contact, including swimming, fishing and boating and eating whole fish, shellfish or crustaceans from the lake. This advice remains in place.

Forest Fire Management Victoria Otway District manager David Roberts said people should avoid the affected water until the algae disperses and warning signs are removed.

"Direct contact with blue-green algae can cause allergic reactions such as skin rashes or itchiness, sore eyes ears and nose or, if swallowed, gastroenteritis, nausea or vomiting," he said.

"Anyone who comes into contact with contaminated water should immediately wash in fresh water and seek medical advice if they experience any illness.

"Water from the lake should not be used for drinking, cooking or other domestic uses."

urn:contentItem:5TJT-5W11-F0J6-J4P0-00000-00Airport changes expand capacity2018-10-25T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:58:16ZLexisNexisAirport changes expand capacity

The $2.2 million Corryong Airport Precinct Development project has been opened.

Works began last year on a new building, runway resurfacing, taxiway extension and lighting upgrades.

The upgrades mean Forest Fire Management Victoria can relocate firefighting and suppression activities from the grass airfield at Avondale to Corryong.

Restrictions on night-time landing and inadequate infrastructure were previous barriers to the precinct being utilised to its full potential.

Northern Victoria MP Jaclyn Symes said the upgrade, funded by the Department of Environment, Land, Water and Planning, Regional Jobs and Infrastructure Fund and the Towong Council, provided long-term benefit and potentially opened up tourism.

"Aircraft play a key role in bushfire response, assisting ground crews to contain fires burning on both public and private land, and I am very pleased the Andrews Labor Government have delivered for the North East again," she said.

urn:contentItem:5SB8-2BF1-F0J6-J4BH-00000-00Planned burns in the Grampians2018-05-16T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:58:16ZLexisNexisPlanned burns in the GrampiansAlice Rennison

Forest Fire Management Victoria are aiming to do planned burns in the Grampians over the next few months.

"We're planning on doing burns in places such as Mount William," FFMV Wimmera district manager Glenn Rudolph said.

"Around spring time we are planning on doing township burns in Stawell and Ararat. These are critical to the town."

FFMV did planned burns around the Grampians region last week, including in Pomonal and Boronia Track.

Planned burns "are important", Mr Rudolph said.

"People can do their own burns on private property." Mr Rudolph urges people planning to do private burns to "contact the CFA if you're in doubt".

urn:contentItem:5SB8-2BF1-F0J6-J4D0-00000-00Planned burns in the Grampians2018-05-16T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:58:16ZLexisNexisPlanned burns in the GrampiansAlice Rennison

Forest Fire Management Victoria are aiming to do planned burns in the Grampians over the next few months.

"We're planning on doing burns in places such as Mount William," FFMV Wimmera district manager Glenn Rudolph said.

"Around spring time we are planning on doing township burns in Stawell and Ararat. These are critical to the town."

FFMV did planned burns around the Grampians region last week, including in Pomonal and Boronia Track.

Planned burns "are important", Mr Rudolph said.

"People can do their own burns on private property." Mr Rudolph urges people planning to do private burns to "contact the CFA if you're in doubt".

urn:contentItem:5WX2-D7F1-F0J6-J2B6-00000-00Cutlery covered in unknown paste removed from Bendigo walking trail2019-08-27T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:58:16ZLexisNexisCutlery covered in unknown paste removed from Bendigo walking trailTara Cosoleto

COUNCIL has removed a number of stainless steel forks, knives and spoons that were left scattered on the Long Gully trail.

Bendigo resident Tim House notified council after he found the cutlery covered in an unknown substance as he walked along the track on Monday afternoon.

The City of Greater Bendigo said they have since removed the cutlery. The unknown paste has been identified as a type of glue.

Mr House said he was concerned someone purposefully left the items to harm pets who use the trail.

Read more: Central Victoria pet owners warned to confine pets during Forest Fire Management Victoria fox baiting program

"The paste looks like peanut butter but you can see the green in it," he said. "It has a stinky, chemical smell. It smells a bit like snail bait.

"It's a serious thing. We walk our dogs out there and so do a lot of other people. There's just no need for it."

Bendigo police said they have not been to any jobs in the area and could not provide any other information on the matter.
